titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Lewis G. Longsworth papers, Rockefeller University Faculty FA177

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-10-16 00:09:16 -0400.

did.unittitle: Lewis G. Longsworth papers, Rockefeller University Faculty

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Lewis Gibson Longsworth, researcher in physical chemistry at The Rockefeller University from 1930 until his retirement in 1970 with researches and publications on the electrochemistry of salt and protein solutions with applications in biology and medicine. His major interest has been in the determination of mobilities, first of small ions, then of macromolecules such as protein and finally of uncharged particles that do not respond to an electric field.

eventgrp.event: A. B. Southwestern College, Winfield, Kansas
M. A. Kansas University, Lawrence, Kansas
Ph. D. Kansas University, Lawrence, Kansas
National Research Council Fellow at The Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research, New York City
Assistant in Physical Chemistry, RIMR, New York City
Associate in Physical Chemistry, RIMR, N. Y. C.
Associate Member, RIMR, N. Y. C.
Member and Professor, Rockefeller University, N. Y. C.
Moundbuilder Citation for Distinguished Service Southwestern College
American Chemical Society Award in Chromatography and Electrophoresis
Professor Emeritus, The Rockefeller University (Closed laboratory)

bioghist.p: Served: Civilian investigator on Manhattan Project OSRD 1941-1942, Editorial Boards of: Journal of The American Chemical Society; Journal of General Physiology; Journal of Colloid Science, National Academy of Sciences: Committee oh Battery and Additives, 1953-1961; Committee to Evaluate a Classified Project of Bureau of Ships, 1962

Member of: National Academy of Sciences, New York Academy of Science (Vice-president 1944), American Chemical Society, Electrochemical Society, Harvey Society, Sigma Xi, Phi Beta Kappa, Alpha Chi Sigma

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Professional correspondence, collected reprints, slides, and other special formats (transparencies, prints, illustrations, and negatives).

Boxes 1 and 2 consist of biographical material, bibliography and collected reprints. Primarily a collection of professional correspondence (1935-1969). Correspondence consists of exchanges of scientific information, discussions of problems and suggested approaches for design and use of apparatus; discussion of experimental results and calculations. Includes frequent examples of detailed analyses and calculations to assist in the experimental work, calculation or interpretation of diffusion and electrophoretic work done in other laboratories or other investigators. Some correspondence deals with arrangements for conferences.
Box 3 contains slides. Boxes 4-17 contain slides and other special formats (transparencies, prints, illustrations, and negatives).

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Boxes 1 and 2 are arranged in alphabetical and chronological order. Correspondence arranged in alphabetical order by correspondent. The number of items is shown by figure in parentheses.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Access to this collection is restricted pending permission from Rockefeller University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Boxes 1 and 2 are arranged in alphabetical and chronological order.
